content.html:
Here's a little help from Omar. Read it carefully!

"That one was tough!" said Omar. "We have six seeds in each packet, and we have four seed packets. To write a multiplication expression for this situation, the first thing you need to do is write an addition expression for the situation"

Aria paused. "Six seeds in each seed packet, four seed packets, that's 6 + 6 + 6 + 6!" she said. 

"Correct," said Omar. "In 6 + 6 + 6 + 6, you are adding 6 to itself 4 times. In a multiplication expression, the first factor is the number you are adding. The second factor is the number of times you are adding it. "

"Because we are adding 6 to itself 4 times, the multiplication expression is 6 * 4."

Meet Aria!

Aria is a young girl who loves spending time with her father. We’ll follow Aria as she learns about multiplication equations and how to use them.

You should know the following before going on:

  • How to write and solve addition expressions

  • How to tell the “place values” in a number (e.g. ones, tens, hundreds, etc.)

You should also get some paper and a pen or pencil, and find a quiet place to work. Take your time. Understanding is more important than speed!

Once you’re ready, click Continue to get started!

hi.html:
Aria se Mil lo!

Aria ek Chhoti ladki hai jo apane pita ke saath samay bitaana pasand karatee hai. ham Aria ke saath chalenge jab vah gunan sameekaranon ke baare mein seekhti hai aur unaka upayog kaise karatee hai.

aage badhane se pahale aapako pata hona chaahie:

atirikt abhivyaktiyon ko kaise likhana aur hal karana hai

ek sankhya mein "sthaan maan" kaise bataen .

aapako kuchh kaagaj aur ek pen ya pencil bhee milanee chaahie, aur kaam karane ke lie ek shaant jagah dhundo. Bina kisi jaldi ke, aaram se kahaani padho! taiyaar hone ke baad, Continue button par click karo!

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. Before you begin this new story with Aria, go back and make sure you understand how addition works. This is important! After you have done this, come back and try again.

content.html:
“What is multiplication?” Aria asked.

“Good question!” Omar said. “Multiplication is just repeated addition, which means that it helps us add the same number together multiple times. In our garden, we can use it for lots of useful things, like knowing how much total space to prepare for all the plants and how much to water each plant."

"But first, say we have six baskets with three apples in each. What addition expression could you use to find the total number of apples?”

hi.html:
"guna kya hota hai?" aariya ne poochha.

"achchha prashn!" Omar ne kaha. “Jab hum ek sankhya ko ussi ke saath kaee baar add kardete hain, toh hum uska guna karte hain. Iska upyog karke, hum pata laga sakte hain ki bagheeche ko kaise vibhaajit kiya jaye.”

"lekin pahale, socho ki agar hamaare paas 6 tokree hai, aur har tokri mein 3 seb rakhe hain. seb ki sankhya ko pata lagane ke lie aap kis atirikt abhivyakti ka upayog kar sakate hain?"

content.html:
Congratulations, you and Aria have finished the first step of your gardening journey! As you learn more about multiplication, you can help Aria with planting her garden!

In this lesson, you learned about... 

  • How addition expressions can be simplified using multiplication expressions
  • The parts of a multiplication expression

In the next lesson, you’ll begin to start solving your first multiplication problems to figure out how much space each plant needs to grow.

Aria’s father, Omar, has started gardening so that he and Aria can eat fresh fruits and vegetables. When the fruits and vegetables are fully grown, they can cook tasty dishes with them!

To plant their vegetables and fruits, Aria and Omar need to figure out how to set up their garden. Today, you will be helping them!

Yesterday, Omar bought seeds at the store. To learn how to plant them, Aria put all the seed packets on a table and read the planting instructions written on them.

“Dad, all of these plants need different amounts of space to grow! How should we split up the space in our garden to make sure that each plant has enough space?” Aria asked.

“This looks like a good chance to use multiplication!” Omar said.

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not right. Let's have Omar explain the answer to us so we understand!

content.html: "Great job!" said Omar. "Now, Aria, I bought four vegetable seed packets yesterday. If each seed packet has six seeds, what multiplication expression can I use to find the total number of vegetable seeds we have to plant this week?"

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that is not right. Count the number of times you are adding 7 to itself in 7 + 7 + 7 + 7 + 7. Then, take that number of times and multiply it by 7 to get your multiplication expression.

content.html: "Okay Aria!" says Omar. "Now, how do you write 7 + 7 + 7 + 7 + 7 as a multiplication expression?"

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. The factor "4" is repeated two times, but it is still counted as two factors. Count all the numbers separated by "*" to get the total number of factors! Try again.
No, that's not correct. Count all the numbers separated by "*" to get the total number of factors! Try again.

content.html:
"Good work, Aria!" said Omar. "Now, know that in a multiplication expression, you can have two or more factors multiplied together!"

"Cool!" said Aria. "How many factors does 2 * 4 * 5 * 23 * 2 have?"

"You tell me!" said Omar.

feedback.html: Yes, correct!
No, this is not quite right. These two numbers are factors, but they are not the ONLY factors. 4, 2, and 3 are all factors in this multiplication expression. Let's try a similar problem
No, that's not right. Make sure to choose all the factors, and try again!

content.html:
"Let's try another one!" said Omar.

"In the multiplication expression below, which numbers are factors?"

4 * 2 * 3 = 24

No, that's not right. Try again!

content.html: "Great job!" said Omar. "Now, what do you call the 2 in the following equation? 2 * 5 * 10 = 100."

feedback.html: Correct. Well done!
Be careful! 7 + 8 + 9 = 24 has 24 as the answer, but this is an addition expression. Only multiplication expressions can have products. Try again!
Be careful! 24 is a factor in 24 * 2 = 48, and an addend in 24 + 1 = 25. The question is asking in which expressions 24 is a product. Try again!
No, that's not right. Try again!

content.html: In which of the following equations is 24 a product? Select all choices that are correct.

Here's a little help from Omar. Read it carefully!

The two (or more) numbers being multiplied together in a multiplication expression are called factors.

  • In 3 * 4 = 12, 3 and 4 are factors

The answer to a multiplication expression is called the product

  • In 3 * 4 = 12, 12 is a product.

When you understand, press Continue to move on!

feedback.html: Correct, good job :)
No, that's not right. The product is not always the rightmost number. The product is the answer when all the factors are multiplied together. 2 is a factor. Try again!
No, that's not right. Remember that the product is the answer to a multiplication equation. Try again!

content.html: "Which number in the following multiplication equation is the product?" 24 = 2 * 3 * 2 * 2

feedback.html: Correct. Good job!
No, this is not right. This is an addition expression, not a multiplication expression. Read the question carefully and try again!
No, that's not right. Remember that multiplication is just repeated addition. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html: We have six seeds in each row, and we have three rows. Before writing a multiplication expression, try writing an addition expression for this situation.
An addition expression you could use for this scenario is: 6 + 6 + 6.

After you have an addition expression, you can write a multiplication expression.

The first number in your multiplication expression should be the number you are adding. The second number should be the number of times you are adding that number. The two numbers should have a "*" between them.

content.html:
While Aria and Omar are organizing their seeds, Omar finds some loose seeds that are not in packets.

What multiplication expression can be used to find the total number of seeds Omar found? Use a hint if you get stuck!

content.html:
"Good job, Aria!" said Omar. "Now that you know about multiplication expressions and their parts, let's test your understanding!"

"In 3 * 4 = 12, what is 12 called?"

feedback.html: Well done! That's right!
No, that's not right. This is the one of the factors. The product of a multiplication is the answer when the factors are multiplied together. Try again!
No, that's not right. Try again!

content.html: Which number(s) in this multiplication expression is the product? 9 * 2 = 18

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not right. Remember that multiplication is just repeated addition. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

content.html:
“You're getting it! Since multiplication is just adding a number to itself lots of times, you can turn addition expressions with the same number into multiplication expressions.” Omar said.

"How would you translate 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 into a multiplication expression?”

“Great job, Aria! Now, let's learn the names for the parts in a multiplication expression.” Omar said.

“The numbers being multiplied together are called factors. The answer we get when those numbers are multiplied together is called the product."

feedback.html: Good job!
No, that's not right. Remember that multiplication is just repeated addition. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

No, that's not right. Remember that multiplication is just repeated addition. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html: <oppia-noninteractive-image alt-with-value="&quot;In 3 * 5 = 15, 3 and 5 are factors. 15 is a product.&quot;" caption-with-value="&quot;&quot;" filepath-with-value="&quot;img_20200601_192422_4k5hqbzbuy_height_237_width_490.png&quot;"></oppia-noninteractive-image>
In a multiplication expression, the numbers being multiplied together are factors, and the answer (after the equal sign) is the product. In 4 * 6 = 24, 4 and 6 are factors. 24 is a product.

content.html: In the multiplication equation '2 * 3 = 6', which numbers are factors?

feedback.html: Correct!
No, this is a factor. Try again!
No, that's not right. The product is one of the three numbers in this multiplication expression: 5, 3, or 15. Try again!

content.html: Identify the product in the following multiplication equation: 5 * 3 = 15.

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. 9 * 9 means adding 9 to itself 9 times, or 9 + 9 + 9 + 9 + 9 + 9 + 9 + 9 + 9. The question is asking how to write 9 + 9 as a multiplication expression. Try again!
No, that's not right. Remember that multiplication is just repeated addition. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

content.html: How would you write 9 + 9 as a multiplication expression?

feedback.html: Yes, that's right! The multiplication expression for 1 is 1 * 1.
No, that's not right. 1 * 0 = 0 because 1 * 0 means adding 1 zero times. The question is asking which multiplication expression you can use to get a product of 1. Try again!
No, this is not right. 1 + 1 + 1 is an addition expression. The question is asking for a multiplication expression which equals 1. Try again.
No, that's not right. Multiplying anything by 0 gives a product of 0. Try again!
No, that's not right. Remember that multiplication is just repeated addition. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

content.html: How would you translate 1 into a multiplication expression?

"Yes!" said Omar. "Now, to find the total number of apples, we can use 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3, but that's a LOT of numbers to write down. To make things easier for us, we can write it as a multiplication expression instead."

 

"3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 can be written as 3 × 6," said Omar. "In a multiplication expression, the first number is the number you are repeatedly adding, the second number is the number of times you are adding it, and the little cross between the 3 and 6 means multiplication. You can read the little cross as 'times'."

"By the way," he continued, "people sometimes use a star instead (3 * 6) when typing because it's hard to type a cross on the keyboard."

"Got it!" said Aria. "So, 3 * 6 is equal to 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 because both expressions mean we are adding 3 to itself 6 times!"

hi.html:
"haan!" omar ne kaha. "ab, seb kee sankhya ka pata lagaane ke lie, ham 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 ka upayog kar sakate hain, lekin yah bohot lamba hai. hamaare lie cheejon ko aasaan banaane ke lie, ham ise guna ke roop mein likh sakate hain.

  umar ne kaha, "3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 ko 3 × 6 likha ja sakata hai." "ek gunan abhivyakti mein, pahalee sankhya vah sankhya hai jise aap baar-baar add rahe hain (3), aur kitni baar usko add rahe ho, wo doosaree sankhya hai (6), aur 3 aur 6 ke beech ke chhote cross ka  hai. aap chhote kros ko is roop mein padh sakate hain" baar "." "vaise," unhonne jaaree rakha, "log kabhee-kabhee taip karate samay (3 * 6) ke bajaay ek staar ka upayog karate hain, kyonki keebord par kros taip karana kathin hai." "samajh gaya!" aariya ne kaha. "to, 3 * 6 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 ke baraabar hai, kyonki donon abhivyaktiyon ka matalab hai ki ham 3 ko 6 baar add kar rahe hain!"

content.html:
"Let’s try another example," said Omar. 

"In this picture, there are 5 square plots of soil in each row, and there are two rows."

"To find the total number of square plots using multiplication, let's start by writing an addition expression first," said Omar. "In this case, that is 5 + 5." 

"Now, because 5 + 5 means adding 5 two times, the multiplication expression would be 5 × 2!"

"Wait," said Aria. "We can also write it as 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2, right? So, does that mean that, here, we can write 2 × 5 as well?"

"Yes, that's correct, too!" said Omar.

hi.html: umar ne kaha, "aaie ek aur udaaharan dekhen." pratyek pankti mein mittee ke 5 bhaagon, aur 2 panktiyon hai " umar ne kaha, "gunan ka upayog karake bhaagon kee sankhya pata lagane ke lie, pahale ek atirikt abhivyakti likhakar shuroo karen." "is maamale mein, vah 5 + 5 hai." "ab, kyonki 5 + 5 ka matalab hai 5 ko do baar add karna, guna abhivyakti 5 × 2 hogee!" "ruko," aariya ne kaha. "ham ise 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 ke roop mein bhee likh sakate hain, theek hai? to, kya isaka matalab hai ki, yahaan, ham 2 × 5 bhee likh sakate hain?" "haan, yah bhee sahee hai!" umar ne kaha.

exploration.title: Parts of Multiplication Expressions
exploration.objective: Learn what multiplication is, how to write expressions to solve it, and how to use it!
